US

House to vote on stopgap bill at 7pm ET/12am GMT

US President Trump said government 'could very much' shutdown, but it is up to the Democrats. US Senate Majority Leader McConnell, however, is confident the House will pass the bill later on Thursday, though McConnell said he was prepared for a shutdown, Politico reported.

Separately, Fox News reported that some lawmakers are preparing to remain in Washington over the weekend to resolve any government spending issues, citing Capitol Hill sources.

The bill is likely to face opposition from some House Republicans, with the Freedom Caucus’ leader Meadows suggesting that between 22-25 members of Republican members of the Caucus would vote against the Bill.

While the GOP is likely to pass the bill in the House, it will need support from Democrats for the Senate vote, which is yet to be scheduled. But with that said, Politico reported that Senate Democrats say they have votes to block government funding bill, once again raising the spectre of a government shutdown, while there were also comments from US Sen. Flake who suggested that they are also discussing a 5-day stop-gap spending bill.

EQUITIES: S&P 500 -0.16% at 2798, DJIA -0.36% at 26021, NDX +0.02% at 6811

Top performers: Tech +0.15%, Telecom +0.14%, Healthcare +0.03%%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.78%, Energy -0.78%, Industrials -0.5%

 

US stocks were mixed, trading negative in early trade after rising to new record highs this week, though the S&P 500 seemed to be clinging to the 2800 mark, while the Dow Jones was hovering around 26,000. In later trade, however, stock indices were content to look through warnings of a Government shutdown, and the S&P 500 was lifted to fresh highs, before falling again as it emerged that Democrat opposition in the Senate is likely to be a stumbling block, likely leading to a government shutdown.

Telecoms were leading gains, with Viacom an outperformer on merger hopes with CBS. Industrials were lagging, after Boeing – the best performer on the Dow in 2018 –  after it was reported that Emirates would purchase 36 A380 aircraft from rival Airbus, dragging on the industrials sector.  Utilities underperformed and energy stocks tracked early weakness in crude prices.

TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 6+ ticks lower at 122-14+

The US Treasury curve bear steepened after China reported solid growth data for Q4, and the steepness was maintained as we entered North American trade. Additionally, news that Apple was set to repatriate a large amount of offshore capital helped keep the risk mood firm. Benchmark 10-year yields rose above 2.62% during US trade.

Some – like Doubleline’s Jeffrey Gundlach – have suggested that the 2.63% level is the key level to watch.

A large amount of investment-grade supply – including from a few key US banks – also helped yields nudge higher in the session.

In afternoon trade, the US Treasury sold $13bln of 10-year TIPS, with the auction stopping-through the screens by 2.7bps, helping US breakeven yields to extend their gains.

The US Treasury announced unchanged sizes for next week's 2-year and 5-year auctions, though cut the 7-year auction amount to USD 28bln (Prev. 2s at USD 26bln, 5s at USD 34bln, 7s at USD 29bln).

Thursday’s economic data:

US Housing Starts Number MM (Dec) 1.192M vs. Exp. 1.275M (Prev. 1.297M, Rev. 1.299M)
US Building Permits: Number (Dec) 1.302M vs. Exp. 1.290M (Prev. 1.303M)
US Initial Jobless Claims (w/e) 220k vs. Exp. 250k (Prev. 261k)
US Continued Jobless Claims (w/e) 1.952M vs. Exp. 1.900M (Prev. 1.867M, Rev. 1.876M)
US Philly Fed Business Indx (Jan) 22.2 vs. Exp. 25.0 (Prev. 26.2, Rev. 27.9)
Canadian ADP Nonfarm employment change (Jan) -7.1k (Prev. 59.2k, Rev. 58.8k)

UK/EU

UK PM May said the UK/EU relationship post-Brexit should cover the services industry, says London will continue to be a major global financial centre. (Newswires)

French President Macron said if the UK wants access to the single market, it can choose between the Norway model or full-membership. (Newswires)


FX

USDJPY drifted to beneath the 111.00 handle, despite yield differentials moving in the USD’s favour; chunky option expiries were likely to blame, with around $3bln rolling-off between 110.80 and 111.00 at the new your cut. The dollar was also pressured by political headlines raising the possibility that a stopgap spending bill would not be passed by Friday night, likely leading to a government shutdown. As the session wore on, the 111.00 was reclaimed.

Cable continues to stalk the 1.39 handle on a mixture of greenback weakness as well as optimism regarding Brexit. Today’s focus was on a press conference between UK PM May and her French counterpart. While the two generally avoided direct comments regarding Brexit, the French PM said say that if the UK wants access to the single market, it can choose between the Norway model or full-membership. May, however, said that the UK/EU relationship post-Brexit should cover the services industry, says London will continue to be a major global financial centre.

The EUR wasn’t swayed by further ECB chatter on Thursday, with speakers largely avoiding comments relating to current policy ahead of next week’s ECB meeting.

COMMODITIES

WTI futures settle 2 cents lower at $63.95 per barrel; Brent futures settle 7 cents lower at $69.31 per barrel

Crude pared back losses after weekly inventory data showed crude stocks drawing down by 6.9mln barrels in the latest week, while stocks at the Cushing hub fell by 4.184mln – the largest weekly fall on record. Crude production rose by 2.7% in the week, taking it to 9.75mln barrels per day.

OPEC’s monthly oil market report, meanwhile, saw the cartel raise its forecasts for non-member supply in 2018. In terms of OPEC members, output rose in Nigeria though declined in Venezuela. Compliance with the cuts deal was said to be running at 129%.

Elsewhere, Nigeria’s Delta Avengers have threatened oil sector attacks, though prices weren’t swayed.

FX Daily Wrap: Usd loses a bit more recovery momentum
content:
DXY

The Greenback has gradually slipped from best levels vs its G10 rivals (and EM currencies) and only remains firmer on the day vs the Loonie after US President Trump’s negative NAFTA tweet (bad joke jibe). The Index has slipped back below 90.500 from just above 91.000, and option interest could well have impacted into the NY cut as Usd/Jpy reversed from near 111.50 highs towards and then through 111.00 to a circa 110.90 low, bang in the middle of 110.80 and 111.00 expiries (1.5 bn or thereabout at each strike). Back to Usd/Cad, a 1.2460 expiry may also have influenced direction as the pair squeezed up to 1.2480 from around 1.2430 before easing back. Eur/Usd and Cable climbed steadily after some choppy trade to stand at 1.2250+ and just under 1.3900 respectively, but the Chf, Aud and Nzd all managed to reclaim big figure or round number status as the US Dollar waned again, sub-0.6600 (but not quite as low as yesterday), 0.8000 and 0.7300-plus respectively. Tech-wise, the DXY needs to hold above the 90.100 area to avoid heavier declines, while the fundamental focus switches to EIA crude and product inventories before the House vote on the stop-gap spending bill.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Chinese GDP beats consensus to grow at its fastest rate in 2yr
content:
18th January 2018

  • European equities inching higher amid the bounce back in the US.
  • Chinese GDP beats consensus to grow at its fastest rate in 2yr.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include; US Building Permits & Jobless claims, alongside DoE Crude Inventory report.

ASIA

Asia stocks were mixed as the region faltered in late trade and gave up the momentum from Wall St. where the S&P 500 and DJIA closed above 2800 and 26000 respectively amid earnings optimism, as well as reports that Apple is to repatriate some of its cash holdings and invest in the US. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) both gained at the open in which the Japanese benchmark briefly rose above the 24000 level for the first time in around 27 years, although both then pared gains with Japanese stocks sliding into the close, while commodity-related stocks in Australia were dampened by disappointing production updates from Whitehaven Coal and Woodside Petroleum. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were varied in anticipation of tier-1 China data releases including GDP in which officials including Premier Li had suggested the economy grew 6.9% for 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat uneventful with early short-covering seen in prices after yields rose to a 6-month high of above 0.08%. Furthermore, mixed 30yr auction results and source reports that some at the BoJ were said to see a need for future normalization talks, failed to garner a reaction, as they also agreed that current stimulus was needed for the time-being.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day, CNY 70bln via 14-day and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4401 (Prev. 6.4335)

Chinese GDP YY (Q4) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%)
- Retail Sales YY (Dec) 9.4% vs. Exp. 10.2% (Prev. 10.2%)
- Industrial Output YY (Dec) 6.2% vs. Exp. 6.1% (Prev. 6.1%)

China House Prices YY (Dec) 5.3% (Prev. 5.1%). (Newswires)

China Property Prices rose M/M in 57 out of 70 cities (Prev. 50) and rose Y/Y in 61 out of 70 cities (Prev. 59).

NDRC official stated that Chinese 2017 GDP grew by 6.9% vs. Exp. 6.8%. (Newswires)

Bank of Korea kept its 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected. (Newswires)

BoK stated that the decision was unanimous and will maintain accommodative policy stance to ensure economic recovery continues and CPI stabilizes at target in mid-term.

EU/UK/US

ECB's Weidmann said that marked reduction in German growth potentially could translate into lower long-term interest rates. (Newswires)

UK RICS Housing Survey (Dec) 8 vs. Exp. -1 (Prev. 0). (Newswires)
 

EQUITIES

European equities inching higher this morning following on from the bounce back seen on Wall Street, which had stemmed from reports that Apple are to pledge a USD 350bln contribution to the US economy. Additionally, optimism over a potential passing of a stop-gap funding bill to prevent a government shutdown also buoyed demand for equities. Elsewhere, encouraging Chinese GDP data helped aid sentiment with China reporting the fastest growth in 2yrs. IT names outperforming in Europe with Infineon shares rising some 4% after a positive note out from Goldman Sachs. FTSE 100 struggling thus with the index dragged down by the likes of Whitbread after a soft earnings report.

FX

The Usd Index extended recovery gains to just over 91.000 overnight, but quickly backed off again despite supportive impulses via data, rising Treasury yields and another solid Fed Beige Book. The Greenback is now relatively mixed within ranges vs G10 counterparts, around 1.2200 against the Eur, 111.25 vs the Jpy and with Cable back down between 1.3800-50 after a spike to 1.3942 (new peak since the Brexit vote). Back to Usd/Jpy, and some large option expiries could well provide some direction today, with 1.4 bn at the 111.00 strike and 1.5 bn at 110.80, while on the upside there is key chart resistance at 111.74 (200 DMA) and 111.97 (50% Fib). For Eur/Usd, if 1.2200 is breached again on the downside then stops are reportedly seen below 1.2150, while 1.2119 is tech support ahead of the next big figure. Aud and Nzd both firming up again vs their US counterpart towards 0.8000 and 0.7300 after the former traded in a volatile fashion on mixed jobs data. In terms of crosses, Eur/Gbp has seen offers around 0.8830 filled, but bids at 0.8800 and strong chart support around 0.8792 are forming a base.  

Australian Employment Change (Dec) 34.7k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 61.6k, Rev. 63.6k). (Newswires)

Australian Unemployment Rate (Dec) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.4% (Prev. 5.4%)
 

FIXED INCOME

More downside pressure in the debt markets, and US Treasury led as the 10 year benchmark yield inches another basis point closer to the 2.63-64% area that many chartists and cash traders have been flagging if not targeting. Bunds have now been down to 160.32, -1/2 point on the day and just 2 ticks shy of tech support that stands in front of the January low so far at 160.11. Accordingly, 10 year German yields are within a whisker of 0.6%, albeit on the relatively new 2028 bond.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures marginally lower despite last nights wider than expected drawdown in the latest API crude report. Price action in oil largely dictated by the mild recovery seen in the USD-index.

Saudi Aramco is to boost refining capacity to 8mln-10mln bpd from 5mln bpd. (Newswires)

US API weekly crude stocks (12 Jan, w/e) -5.120M vs. Exp. -3.500M (Prev. -11.190M). (Newswires)

DAILY BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply from UK, Spain and France
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: Spanish EUR 3.5-4.5bln 0.45% 2022, 2.35% 2033, 2.9% 2046 Bond Auction

Analysts at IFR state that there is not a particularly constructive set up for the auctions as there is only a natural concession for the 5-yr issue, whereas there is no concession for the two longer bonds. There is also little micro RV, and all issues have outperformed swaps. Likewise, Spain is still generally looking expensive to Italy on a cross market basis, so there is unlikely to be much switching, unless investors think the spread will widen further if the Italian elections in March cause any political stress. However they still foresee the auctions passing without too much issue as there is little credit negative news in the market at the moment.

2.35% 2033 prev. b/c 1.78 and average yield 1.184%

AUCTION PREVIEW: UK GBP 2.25bln 0.75% 2023 Gilt Auction

Since the last tap yields are higher by around 7bp, so there is a modest degree of natural concession built into the tap. The strength of the sale will no doubt focus on the curve where there is around 4bp of relevant value on the mismatched fly between the 1T22s and the 2Q23s. Also bear mind that at this level, the bond will be the cheapest in the 5-year sector of the Gilt curve on an asset swap basis, which is likely to be the case until the stock reaches benchmark size.

Historical Data

0.75% Jul’2023 Prev. b/c 2.1, average yield 0.889% and a tail of 0.3bps

Bids are submitted by 1030GMT and results are published shortly after.

 

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 13bln in 10-year TIPS on 18 January at 1300 ET/1800 GMT

- US Treasury will auction a new January 2028 TIPS bond, which will likely have a 0.5% coupon, according to analysts.

- “The new bond is being quoted at +3.25bp in real yield spread vs the current benchmark in the WI indications,” Societe Generale writes. “This is equivalent to +3.75bp after taking into account the (negative) carry to month-end.” The bank says that this would be equivalent to a breakeven of around 2.007% vs the Tsy Nov 2027.

 

- The current 10y benchmark TIP trades at a spot breakeven around 2.04%, the last January benchmark (Jan 2027) trades around 2.01%.

- SocGen says that valuation appear fair, and are being supported by the recent gains in energy prices. However, the bank argues that it trades rich on the curve as well as when compared to recent history.

- The bank also notes that Q1 tends to be a good quarter for flows into TIPS, due to seasonality. “Recent flow into TIPS has been particularly good, as was the case in early 2017. In particular, net flow into ETFs was strong in November, December and the first two weeks of January, averaging close to $1bn. The same has been the case for open-ended TIPS funds, with December seeing the largest net positive flow since the post-US-election months.”

- SocGen expects the auction to be well received, arguing that momentum and technicals are supportive factors, while the bank believes that breakevens have further to run, despite being at eh top of the range of the last year.

- In terms of participation, foreign investors have taken down a decent amount of new TIPS. Cover, meanwhile, has tended to be etween 2.3x and 2.6x since the Treasury cut volumes of TIPS.

content: The core 10 year Eurex bond is just inching down to new lows and support around 160.45, with 160.30 next on the radar for bears before the month to date base at 160.11 where stops are said to be in place and could expose 160.00 quickly ahead of 159.78. content: Early slippage along the Short Sterling strip, in part perhaps on an unexpected rebound in the RICS hpb overnight, but mainly on the back of a broad upturn in rates/yields on upbeat data (ie US ip and Chinese GDP) and more hawkish/less dovish global CB perceptions. Gilts are also heading for a bearish Liffe open on similar rationale, and with DMO issuance on the agenda and the first real Brexit event of 2018 via the House of Lords vote on the EU Withdrawal bill. The 10 year benchmark bond looks set to kick off Thursday’s session around ¼ point below the 123.99 previous close.

subject: Iraq and BP are to sign an agreement to boost production from the Northern Kirkuk oilfields; according to Iraqi oil officials
Bunds: down with US Treasuries and on firm Chinese GDP
content: A weaker Eurex open in line with leads from USTs, and given some added impetus from above forecast Chinese growth data. The 10 year German debt future was marked down 20 ticks initially and after a fleeting uptick to 160.63 has subsequently extended losses to trade at 160.48 vs Wednesday’s 160.82 close. More chat about the BoJ potentially adding policy normalisation to the agenda, albeit for future implementation, and tangible evidence that Japan and China have slowed US Treasury purchases via the latest (November) TICS data have weighed on bonds, while Apple’s decision to repatriate Usd350 bn for reinvestment and job creation is also impacting the fixed space as 10 year futures slip below key chart support and the corresponding yield heads back up towards 0.6-0.63%. For Bunds/Eurozone paper specifically, eyes/ears on more ECB speakers with Weidmann, Coeure and Villeroy all slated (but also recently airing views), while supply comes from Spain and France in the usual hefty and multi-tranche mid-month auctions.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Apple's pledge to contribute USD 350bln over the forthcoming 5yrs supports US equities and USD
content:
18th January 2018

  • Asian equities failed to be inspired by optimism in the US after it was reported that Apple is said to commit to investing USD 350bln in the US.
  • USD also firms on Apple reports, while AUD is flat despite better than expected Australian jobs report.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Chinese GDP, US Building Permits & Jobless Claims and DoE Crude report.

 

ASIA

Asia stocks were mixed as the region faltered in late trade and gave up the momentum from Wall St. where the S&P 500 and DJIA closed above 2800 and 26000 respectively amid earnings optimism, as well as reports that Apple is to repatriate some of its cash holdings and invest in the US. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) both gained at the open in which the Japanese benchmark briefly rose above the 24000 level for the first time in around 27 years, although both then pared gains with Japanese stocks sliding into the close, while commodity-related stocks in Australia were dampened by disappointing production updates from Whitehaven Coal and Woodside Petroleum. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were varied in anticipation of tier-1 China data releases including GDP in which officials including Premier Li had suggested the economy grew 6.9% for 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat uneventful with early short-covering seen in prices after yields rose to a 6-month high of above 0.08%. Furthermore, mixed 30yr auction results and source reports that some at the BoJ were said to see a need for future normalization talks, failed to garner a reaction, as they also agreed that current stimulus was needed for the time-being.

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day, CNY 70bln via 14-day and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4401 (Prev. 6.4335)

China House Prices YY (Dec) 5.3% (Prev. 5.1%). (Newswires)
China Property Prices rose M/M in 57 out of 70 cities (Prev. 50) and rose Y/Y in 61 out of 70 cities (Prev. 59).

NDRC official stated that Chinese 2017 GDP grew by 6.9% vs. Exp. 6.8%. (Newswires)

Bank of Korea kept its 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected. (Newswires)
BoK stated that the decision was unanimous and will maintain accommodative policy stance to ensure economic recovery continues and CPI stabilizes at target in mid-term.

UK

UK RICS Housing Survey (Dec) 8 vs. Exp. -1 (Prev. 0). (Newswires)

UK House of Commons approved the EU withdrawal bill as expected. (Newswires)

UK and France are said to have reached an agreement regarding border policing. (Newswires)
 

EU

ECB's Nouy is to meet with Bank of Italy officials and banking industry chiefs to discuss NPLs. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, USD firmed in late US trade after reports that Apple were to pay a USD 38bln tax bill to repatriate funds into the US, which saw EUR/USD slip below 1.2200 and GBP/USD retreat from a fresh post-Brexit high above 1.3900. Elsewhere, the strength in the greenback coupled with the heightened risk appetite during US hours pushed USD/JPY above 111.00, while AUD/USD saw a knee-jerk reaction on better than expected Australian Employment Change. However, the gains were then pared as the data also included an unexpected increase in the Unemployment Rate and was also likely influenced by seasonal factors.

Australian Employment Change (Dec) 34.7k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 61.6k, Rev. 63.6k). (Newswires)
Australian Unemployment Rate (Dec) 5.5% vs. Exp. 5.4% (Prev. 5.4%)

COMMODITIES

Commodity prices were mixed with WTI crude futures marginally underpinned to trade back above USD 64/bbl after the latest API inventory data showed a larger than expected drawdown in headline crude stockpiles. Gold languished after having declined about USD 10/oz after Apple’s repatriation announcement spurred a bid tone for the greenback considering that the tech giant is seen to hold USD 250bln in cash overseas.

US API weekly crude stocks (12 Jan, w/e) -5.120M vs. Exp. -3.500M (Prev. -11.190M). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

The US curve experienced bear flattening, as Fed dove Evans (non-voter) stuck to script and Kaplan (non-voter) reiterated his base case of 3 hikes in 2018, although he did note that further monetary tightening could occur if appropriate. US T-Note Futures settled 10+ ticks lower at 122-21. China and Japan, the two biggest foreign U.S. creditors, reduced their holdings of U.S. government debt in November. Chinese holding of US treasuries fell to USD 1.176tln (Prev. USD 1.189tln), marking its lowest in 4-months. Japanese holding of US treasuries fell to USD 1.084tln (lowest since Jun’13).

South Korea and North Korea agreed to march together at PyeongChang and field their first joint Olympic team. (Yonhap)

US Secretary of State Tillerson said he is confident US can get to the negotiating table with North Korea. (Newswires)

US President Trump said that Russia is helping North Korea evade sanctions by filling in gaps left by China. He also stated that China is doing a lot to help on North Korea but could do more. Trump declined to confirm reports that the US is debating a possible pre-emptive strike on North Korea. He also opened that he is not sure that talks with the North Korean leader Kim would lead to anything meaningful.

A North Korean diplomat said that the recent meeting in Vancouver was a “provocation” against North Korea, and is not conducive to peace and talks between the North and South. He also noted that North Korea is determined to fight sanctions and is ready for both “dialogue and confrontation.” (Newswires)
 

US

Fed’s Evans (Non-Voter, Dove) said that he doesn't see much evidence of overshooting on Fed's employment mandate and is worried that the economic cycle might end before inflation gets up to the Fed’s goal. Evans added that something less than 3 hikes this year is probably appropriate and that waiting until mid-year to hike would not rule out 3 hikes this year if required. (Newswires)

Fed’s Beige book said that the economy continued to expand, with most districts saying that wages increased at a modest pace, and most reported modest to moderate price growth. (Newswires)

US President Trump said that he is considering "big damages" in probe over alleged China intellectual property theft and said that he hopes there won't be a trade war with China, but "if there is, there is". President Trump also stated that he may terminate NAFTA agreement and that a lot of people would be unhappy if he did. (Newswires)

US President Trump said a government shutdown is possible and that democrats would be to blame. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Kelly believes congress will pass a stop-gap spending bill to avert a shutdown and said that GOP leaders have the votes to avert a government shutdown. Furthermore, Chief of Staff Kelly also stated that the White House is looking at Mexico paying for the border wall through NAFTA and visa fees. (Newswires)

There were various comments from Congress regarding the spending bill including US Sen. Majority Leader McConnell who stated that he thinks there is a good chance that Congress will pass the stopgap spending bill by the Friday deadline. Conversely, Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham said he will not vote for the stop-gap funding bill, while Freedom Caucus Chair Meadows said House doesn't have enough votes yet to pass stopgap spending bill. (Newswires)

Apple (AAPL) said to accelerate its US investment and to make a contribution of USD 350bln over five years, anticipating to pay a tax repatriation of USD 38bln as required by recent tax law changes. (Newswires)

content:
Asia stocks trade mostly higher as region rides on the momentum from Wall St. where the S&P 500 and DJIA closed above 2800 and 26000 for the first time ever amid earnings optimism, as well as reports that Apple is to repatriate some of its cash holdings and invest in the US. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) both gained at the open in which the Japanese benchmark briefly rose above the 24000 level for the first time in around 27 years, although both then pulled back from intraday highs with the Australian benchmark nearly flat as commodity related stocks are dampened amid disappointing production updates from Whitehaven Coal and Woodside Petroleum. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) are both positive with all focus on the upcoming key Chinese data releases including GDP in which Premier Li had suggested the economy grew 6.9% for 2017, as well as Industrial Production and Retail Sales data.

In FX markets, USD firmed during the prior US session after reports that Apple (AAPL) were to pay a USD 38bln tax bill to repatriate funds into the US, which saw EUR/USD slip below 1.2200 and GBP/USD retreat from a fresh post-Brexit high above 1.3900. Elsewhere, the strength in the greenback coupled with safe-haven outflows pushed USD/JPY above 111.00, while AUD/USD saw a knee-jerk reaction on better than expected Australian Employment Change of 34.7K jobs vs. Exp. 15.0K jobs. However, the gains were then pared as the data also included an unexpected increase in the Unemployment Rate and was also likely influenced by seasonal factors.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful with only mild-short covering seen in prices after yields rose to a 6-month high of above 0.08%. Furthermore, participants are side-lined ahead of a 30yr auction later and source reports that some at the BoJ were said to see a need for future normalization talks, failed to garner a reaction as they also agreed that current stimulus is needed for the time-being.

Bank desk views on the Chinese Q4 GDP release due at 02:00 GMT
content:
ASB: To remain solid on the back of domestic demand and a recovering world economy that is supporting Chinese exports.  According to the Xinhua News Agency, Premier Li Keqiang said the Chinese economy expanded by 6.9% in 2017

Barclays: We expect industrial production growth to remain broadly stable, at 6.1%, in December, as signalled by solid manufacturing PMIs. We forecast fixed asset investment growth will moderate to 7.1% in December, with recovering manufacturing investment partially offsetting an expected slowdown in infrastructure and real estate investment. Growth in retail sales is likely to remain above 10% despite some moderation in auto sales. We view strong exports, robust consumption, and slow but solid investment growth as presenting upside risks to our GDP growth forecast of 6.3% q/q saar (or 6.7% y/y) for Q4 17.

BMO: Look for fourth quarter China real GDP on Thursday, along with industrial production and retail sales for December. Consensus is calling for broader economic growth to slow from 6.8% in Q3 to 6.7% in Q4, which would mark the smallest gain in just over a year, though, broadly speaking, in line with the average pace over the past three years. Rare is the day when this release surprises consensus. For 2018, officials are targeting growth of “around 6.5%” (we are a bit higher at 6.6%), with momentum easing as the PBoC slowly lets market forces have a bit more influence on the yuan, allowing it to strengthen further. That process started earlier this month when it stopped using a “countercyclical adjustment factor” to help calculate the CNY’s daily value. The central bank could easily step back in to guide the currency if there is too much volatility, but they are headed in the right direction. China’s regulators will also continue to cool lending activity at shadow banks (not a bad thing), which will dampen economic growth as well in 2018.

CBA: Chinese GDP remains solid because of domestic demand and a recovering world economy supporting Chinese exports.  According to Xinhua News Agency, Premier Li Keqiang said the Chinese economy expanded by 6.9% in 2017.

HSBC: We estimate the Chinese economy grew at a slower rate of 6.6% y-o-y in Q4 2017, as tougher environmental regulations and winter season production caps impacted activity. That implies GDP growth of 6.7% for 2017 (unchanged from the pace in 2016). Looking ahead, economic growth is likely to remain resilient, supported by the pick-up in global demand and manufacturing investment, even as the property market slows.

Westpac: China GDP has consistently beaten expectations through 2017, spurred on by external demand as well as a robust pipeline of investment projects that are proceeding to completion. It may again be the case that growth surprises to the upside; however, we and the market believe the more likely outcome is that momentum slows a tick from 6.8%yr to 6.7%yr. The basis of this view is partly attributable to the slowdown in investment currently being seen across the economy, in both residential and non-residential construction as well as other investment spending being undertaken by the government and corporates. Also key to the growth story is the consumer. Here we see robust demand, but not enough of an acceleration to more than offset the softening investment pulse.
